0.description: The Gnadenhutten Massacre of Indigenous Americans in 1782.

3.description: Captives being brought on board a slave ship on the West Coast of Africa (Slave Coast), c1880.

5.description: “The ecological consequences of cotton farming and the slave labor...inhibit agriculture in the South to this day.” -- Aaron Joslin

6.description: Modern day enslavement of Uzbekistan children

7.description: Modern slavery: 'Blood diamonds' dug from African mines by children as young as 11

8.description: Despite near-continuous development, oil, gas, and other petrochemical companies are not finished building new factories and refineries in communities of poor Black people

9.description: Environmental racism & slow crises: Chemical plants and factories line the roads and suburbs of the area known as 'Cancer Alley'

10.description: Protestors led by Reverend Joseph Lowery march against a proposed toxic waste dump in Warren County, North Carolina, in October 1982

11.description: Article: Environmental racism in India & Africa

12.description: Environmental Injustice: Protestors block the delivery of toxic PCB waste to a landfill in Afton, North Carolina, 1982

13.description: “Durban Poison” in South Africa:  the largest concentration of petrochemical industries, waste water treatment works, numerous toxic waste landfill sites in the country

14.description: Studies show that communities of color are especially vulnerable to environmental injustice and environmental racism.

0.description: Cotton farming was not only ecologically damaging on the land, but physically and emotionally brutal on the bodies and morales of enslaved Black people
0.title: 12 years a slave cotton field song

1.description: Landfills, chemical waste facilities and power plants are more often built in poor and minority communities, which don't have the power or money to advocate for themselves.
1.title: A brief history of environmental justice

2.description: This piece of work is a bird's eye view of the history by scaling down a month length of time into one second.  No letter is used for equal messaging to all viewers without language barrier.  The blinking light, sound and the numbers on the world map show when, where and how many experiments each country have conducted
2.title: '1945-1998' by ISAO HASHIMOTO

0.title: White Utopia/Black Inferno: Life on a Geologic Spike
0.author: Katherine Yusoff
0.description: The white utopia was a black inferno.    —Sylvia Wynter

1.title: The Human Planet: How We Created the Anthropocene
1.author: Simon L. Lewis & Mark A. Maslin Pelican
1.description: This is the view of two UK scientists who believe the impact of colonialism was so profound it can be detected in Earth’s air and rocks

2.title: Blood and earth: Modern slavery, ecocide, and the secret to saving the world.
2.author: Kevin Bales
2.description: “These two problems, this ancient and terrible problem of slavery and this newer concern that we have about climate change, are actually so tightly linked together that the solutions are fitting both of them,”

3.title: A Billion Black Anthropocenes or None
3.author: Katherine Yusoff
3.description: Yusoff initiates a transdisciplinary conversation between black feminist theory, geography, and the earth sciences, addressing the politics of the Anthropocene within the context of race, materiality, deep time, and the afterlives of geology.

4.title: Blackness and the Pitfalls of Anthropocene Ethics
4.author: Axelle Karera
4.description: This article is concerned with what Srinivas Aravamudan deems “the escapist philosophy of various dimensions of the hypothesis concerning the Anthropocene.”

5.title: Reorientations; or, An Indigenous Feminist Reflection on the Anthropocene
5.author: Kali Simmons
5.description: Destruction of homelands. Loss of kinship species. Exposure to deadly contaminants. Mass extinction. Transformed lifeways. In the face of these radical changes, a question lingers: How long will life be possible?

6.title: The Black Shoals: Offshore Formations of Black and Native Studies
6.author: Tiffany Lethabo King
6.description: In The Black Shoals Tiffany Lethabo King uses the shoal—an offshore geologic formation that is neither land nor sea—as metaphor, mode of critique, and methodology
